Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative 3D Exploration of the Hypothesis of a Plume-Fed Asthensophere
Award.AbstractNarration: Since about 1970, Plate Tectonics - the notion that Earth?s surface is comprised of large, rigid plates that are created at mid-ocean ridges and consumed at trenches - has been the ?standard model? for how the Earth works. Plate motions are known to be a manifestation of thermal convection ? flow driven by high temperatures - but the details of this fundamental process remain poorly understood. The very novel hypothesis that inspires this project is that the uppermost mantle of the Earth, just beneath the plates has been flooded by hot, fluid material supplied by plumes rising from the lower mantle. The project will use 3D numerical experiments to assess the plume fed asthenosphere model (PFA) and its various implications for a wide range of processes. In addition to its contribution to our understanding of Earth processes at the most fundamental level, the broader impacts of this project include contributions to other, related research topics, the development of new computer codes, training a graduate student and participation by undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of mantle plumes holds that an upwelling "plume" of  hot mantle from teh deep interior of the Earth can rise up the base of a tectonic plate, and generate concentrated voluminous volcanic eruptions.  These are known as flood basalts, and represent the largest eruptions known to occur on Earth. A number of these major plume-related eruptions are associated with major extinction events in the geologic record, like the Permo-Triassic (250 Ma, or million years ago) and Cretaceous-Tertiary (65 Ma) extinctions. One curious feature is that plume-related volcanism occurs at the same time, 62 million years ago, in either side of Greenland.  The eruptive sites are 1500 km apart, and traditional plume theory does not predict such widely spaced eruptive centers.  We sought to use 3D models of flow in the mantle, the deep interior of the  Earth, to understand what might cause this unusual phenomenon.  We found that interaction of a large plume with the deep continental roots, or "keel" of Greenland could, under thei right circumstances, produce such as effect. Old continents have deep, relatively cool, and strong keels that extend down 200 or more kilometers into the mantle.  Greenland comprises some of the oldest continental material on Earth, and so is believed to have a deep and well established keel. The key was to include the observation that Greenland "rifted" or separated from Canada (Labrador) on one side and the Scotland region on the other at abou the same time, as the North Atlantic ocean began to form, duing the Paleocene epoch (66 to 56 million years ago).  As Greenland passed over the upwardly migrating plume, first the keel diverted the plum to one side of Greenland and then to the other.  Buut there is a period of time when mantle is flowing up on both sides and is caapable of mkaing large volumes of melt as the hot rock nears the surface and metlts because of decreasing pressure.  So we found that one plume could produce simultaneous volcanism on either side of an old continental fragment like Greenland, as long as the timing was right.
